Detailed Description

The base class of all robotic classes.

The class RoboticObject is the base class of all physical robotic classes (e.g., Manipulator, Gripper, Puma 560, etc.) and all functional robotic classes (e.g., TrajectoryGenerator, ServoControl, etc.). The class RoboticObject defines a generic interface that is common to all of the robotic classes. This allows to perform generic operations on one or multiple objects (e.g., shutdown all objects).

Specifically, RoboticObject defines:

  • Error handling
  • Shutdown behavior
  • Interactive commands
  • Configuration management
  • Functions to determine object and class name
  • GUI control panel functionality
  • Message handling callbacks
  • Thread functionality

Example Program: See the example of the class PhysicalObject

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

RoboticObject ( const TypeInfo * parent ) [protected]
 

The constructor initializes the object name to "noname1", "noname2", ... etc. Note that this constructor is protected, i.e., it is only called from the constructor of a derived class.

~RoboticObject ( ) [virtual]
 

The destructor unregisters the object with the object manager. The destructors of all derived class must call the exit() function as the first statement.

Member Function Documentation

void * operator new ( size_t len )
 

The operator new is reimplemented here from the global operator new to determine wheather a variable was allocated on the heap or on the stack. If it was allocated on the heap, then this function, which stores the address of the allocated block, was called. Later, when registering the object with the object manager, if the address of the registered object is the same as the one stored here, it means the object was allocated on the heap.

const char * getName ( ) const
 

Returns the object name.

Returns:
A pointer to the object name.

void outputInfo ( ostream & stream = cout ) [virtual]
 

Outputs information about the object to an output stream. This class outputs class name, object name, number of threads, QMotor configuration filename, and interactive commands. A derived class needs to first call the outputInfo() function of the parent class and then add items to the output.

Parameters:
stream   Stream to output the information to.

Reimplemented in PhysicalObject.

void exitRoboticPlatform ( )
 

This is a convience function that first sets RoboticPlatform::d_status to the indicate that the exit orginated from this object and also copies the object status to RoboticPlatform::d_status if error. Then, it calls RoboticPlatform::exit().

void finishInit ( ) [virtual]
 

This function is called from the init() functions as the last step right before the object is added to the object manager. At this point, the configuration of the object is setup, the QMotor control program (if existing) is started, and all the threads are started up.

This class performs no action. A derived class needs to first call the finishInit() function of the parent class. A derived class could e.g. use this function to synchronize with the other threads.

Reimplemented in PhysicalObject.

const TypeInfo * getTypeInfo ( ) const [virtual]
 

Returns the type info of the class. The type info can be used to obtain the class name, the parent class name, the parent type info, and to create a new object of the class. See class TypeInfo for more information. Any derived class must implement this function and return a pointer to the s_typeInfo member of the class.

Example: 

     Puma560 puma;
    
     cout << "Class: " << puma.getTypeInfo()->getClassName() << endl;

Reimplemented in FunctionalObject, and PhysicalObject.

void startShutdown ( ) [virtual]
 

This function is called when the object is supposed to shutdown itself. This class performs no action in this function. If a derived class reimplements this function, it should first call the startShutdown() function of the parent class and then perform all necessary action for shutting down the object, especially hardware (e.g., move a manipulator to a safe position before disabling the arm power). The shutdown process can take any amount of time. The object must indicate with the getShutdownProgress() function when the shutdown is complete.

Example: 

     WAM wam;
     ...
     wam.startShutdown();
     while (wam.getShutdownProgress() < 100)
     {
       cout << "Waiting for the WAM to shutdown" << endl;
       sleep(1);
     }

int getShutdownProgress ( ) [virtual]
 

This function is continuously called while the object is shutting down. It returns the percentage of the completion of the shutdown (0 means the shutdown has just begun, 50 means the shutdown is half finished, 100 means the shutdown is complete).

This class always returns 100. The derived class should use the getShutdownProgress() function of the parent class and return a weighted sum of the progress of the parent class and the derived class.

Returns:
The percentage of the shutdown completed (0...100).

int getNumCommands ( ) const [virtual]
 

Returns the number of interactive commands that are associated with the class. This function and the following function are called to create items in the menu that pops up if the user right clicks on an object in the Scene Viewer. A derived class must return the correct number of interactive commands by calling getNumCommands() of the parent class and adding the number of the additional commands.

Returns:
The number of interactive commands.

Example: 

     int Motor::getNumCommands() const
     {
       return PhysicalObject::getNumCommands() + 3;
     }

Reimplemented in PhysicalObject.

const char * getCommandName ( int i ) const [virtual]
 

Returns the name of one of the interactive commands that are associated with the class. A derived class must return the correct command name. The first command defined in every derived class must have the '-' character as the first character.

Parameters:
i   The number of the command name that is requested, or 0 if i does not specify a valid command.
Returns:
A pointer to the command name string.

Example: 

     const char *Motor::getCommandName(int i) const
     {
       if (i < PhysicalObject::getNumCommands())
         return PhysicalObject::getCommandName(i);
       else
       {
         switch (i - PhysicalObject::getNumCommands())
         {
           case 0: return "-Stop Motor"; break;
           case 1: return "Rotate Left"; break;
           case 2: return "Rotate Right"; break;
           default: return 0;
         }
       }
     }

Reimplemented in PhysicalObject.

void doCommand ( int i ) [virtual]
 

Executes one of the interactive commands that are associated with the class. A derived class must perform the action that is associated with the command name returned by getCommandName of the same index i.

Parameters:
i   The number of the command to be performed.

Example 1: 

     const char *Motor::doCommand(int i) const
     {
       if (i < PhysicalObject::getNumCommands())
         return PhysicalObject::doCommand(i);
       else
       {
         switch (i - PhysicalObject::getNumCommands())
         {
           case 0: d_motorVoltage = 0; break;
           case 1: d_motorVoltage = -1; break;
           case 2: d_motorVoltage = 1; break;
           default: return 0;
         }
       }
     }

Example 2: 

     Puma560 puma;
    
     cout << "Execute which command ==> " << endl;
     char command[100];
     cin << command;
    
     int numCommands = puma.getNumCommands();
     for (int i = 0; i < numCommands; i++)
       if (strcmp(puma.getCommandName(i), command) == 0)
         puma.doCommand(i);
     if (i == numCommands)
       cout << "Command " << command << " not found" << endl;

Reimplemented in PhysicalObject.

void createControlPanel ( bool realizeFlag = true ) [virtual]
 

Creates and opens the control panel window of the object. This function is usually called from the pop-up menu of the Scene Viewer, but can also be called from the robot control program directly.

This class creates a window with the class name and the object name in the title bar, and a class icon and the current object status as the only contents of the control panel window.

To add contents to the control panel, a derived class must first check if a control panel is currently open (isControlPanelOpen()), and return if it is open. Then, it must call the createControlPanel() function of its parent class with parameter "false" to avoid calling of realize() (to avoid flickering). After that, the derived class can add contents to the control panel window by creating widgets as a child of d_controlPanelGroup. The first widget created should be a separator widget (see addControlPanelSeparator()). Be sure to wrap your code with RoboticPlatform::lockPhoton() and RoboticPlatform::unlockPhoton() after the call of createControlPanel() of the parent class to allow threaded use. Finally, the derived class should call d_controlPanelWindow->realize() if realizeFlag is true.

Parameters:
realizeFlag   If true, realize the control panel. Set to false, if you call createControlPanel() from the createControlPanel() function of a derived class.

Example: 

     void Motor::createControlPanel(bool realizeFlag = true)
     {
       if (isControlPanelOpen())
         return;
    
       PhysicalObject::createControlPanel();
    
       RoboticPlatform::lockPhoton();
    
       addControlPanelSeparator();
    
       // Add label that displays the speed of the motor
       d_speedLabel = new CLabel(d_controlPanelGroup);
    
       if (realizeFlag)
         d_controlPanelWindow->realize();
       
       RoboticPlatform::unlockPhoton();
     }

Reimplemented in PhysicalObject.

void addControlPanelSeparator ( )
 

This function should be called by the createControlPanel() function of derived classes to create a separator widget between the control panel components.

void closeControlPanel ( ) [virtual]
 

Closes the control panel if currently open. A derived class can reimplement this function if an additional cleanup of memory is required, but it needs to call the closeControlPanel() of the parent class first.

bool isControlPanelOpen ( )
 

Determines if the control panel is currently open.

Returns:
true: The control panel is open, false: The control panel is closed.

void updateGUI ( ) [virtual]
 

Updates the control panel and all additional GUI components that belong to this class. This function is continuously called from the Scene Viewer.

This class updates the status message in the control panel. A derived class must first call the updateGUI() function of its parent class first, then check if the control panel is actually open (then d_controlPanelWindow != 0) and return if not, and finally do its own updates. Be sure to wrap your code with lockPhoton() and unlockPhoton() (after the call of updateGUI()!) to allow threaded use of the control panel. of the parent class.

Example: 

     void Motor::updateGUI()
     {
       if (d_controlPanelWindow == 0)
         return;
    
       PhysicalObject::updateGUI();
    
       RoboticPlatform::lockPhoton();
    
       // Update label that displays the speed of the motor
       d_speedLabel->setTextFromDouble(d_speed);
    
       RoboticPlatform::unlockPhoton();
     }

Reimplemented in PhysicalObject.

CMenu * createPopupMenu ( CWidget * parent,
int x,
int y )
 

Creates a popup menu that displays all interactive commands and processes them.

Parameters:
parent   The parent widget of the popup menu.
x   X-position of the popup menu.
y   Y-position of the popup menu.
Returns:
Pointer to the popup menu.

void handleMessage ( void * message,
int size ) [virtual]
 

Handles a message. Messages are sent by simply calling the function handleMessage(). Messages can be used perform custom generic operations on multiple objects that are not yet part of the class RoboticObject. The base class does no operation. The derived class should call the handleMessage() function of the parent class first, and then process additional messages.

Parameters:
message   Pointer to the message data.
size   Message length in bytes.

void init ( int i = 1 ) [protected]
 

Registers the object with the object manager. Starts additional threads. This function must be called from any constructor of a derived class that allows the user to specifiy the index of the object in the global configuration file. It should be not called from any protected constructor.

This version of init() determines the object name and configuration by reading the i'th section of the global configuration file that has an entry "class" that matches the object's class name.

void init ( const char * objectName ) [protected]
 

Registers the object with the object manager. Starts additional threads. This function must be called from any constructor of a derived class that allows the user to specify the object name. It should not be called from any protected constructor.

This version of init() determines the configuration by reading the section of the global configuration file that is specified by objectName.

void exit ( ) [protected]
 

This function first calls shutdownObject() and waits until the object is shutdown completely, indicated by getShutdownProgress(). Then, it unregisters the object with the object manager and terminates all additional threads. This function must be called as the first function in the destructor. Because the object manager could be locked for deletion of objects by another thread, the exit function can take any time for execution.

void readGlobalConfiguration ( Config * config ) [protected, virtual]
 

Sets up the configuration of the object from the global configuration file. This class sets the name of the QMotor control program configuration file (entry qmotorConfig). A derived class should first call the readGlobalConfiguration() function of the parent class and then read additional settings. The readGlobalConfiguration() function is called from the init(int index) and init(const char *objectName) functions. These functions already lock the configuration with RoboticPlatform::lockGlobalConfiguration, so this must not be done again in readGlobalConfiguration().

Parameters:
config   A pointer to the global configuration.

Example: 

     void MyClass::readGlobalConfiguration(Config *config)
     {
       // Call readGlobalConfiguration() of the parent class
       Parent::readGlobalConfiguration(config);
    
       // Read the channel number from the configuration,
       // default is "2"
       d_channel = config->getIntegerEntry("channel", 2);
     }

Reimplemented in PhysicalObject.

int getNumAdditionalThreads ( ) [protected, virtual]
 

This function returns how many additional threads are required for the operation of the object. The init() functions will create exactly the number of additional threads indicated by getNumAdditionalThreads. This class returns 0. A derived class must first call the getNumAdditionalThreads() function of its parent class and then add its own number of additional threads.

Example: 

     void TemperatureMonitor::getNumAdditionalThreads()
     {
       return PhysicalObject::getNumAdditionalThreads() + 1;
     }

void * thread ( int num ) [protected, virtual]
 

This function executes the additional threads. This function is called in a new thread after object construction, from the init() function. This class performs no action. A derived class must first call the thread function of its parent class. Then, it can run its own additional threads.

Parameters:
num   Number of thread to start (first additional thread has the number 0).
Returns:
0 or a pointer to an exit structure.
Parameters:
<b>Example:<   /b> 

     void TemperatureMonitor::thread(int num)
     {
       if (num < PhysicalObject::getNumAdditionalThreads())
       {
         PhysicalObject::thread(num);
         return;
       }
       \param  
       while (1)
       {
         sleep(1);   // Check temperature every second
         if (readTemperature() > d_maxTemperature)
         {
           RoboticPlatform::shutdownSystem();
           return;
         }
       }
     }

ControlProgram * getQMotorControlProgram ( ) [protected, virtual]
 

This function runs a pointer to the QMotor control program, if the class is derived from the ControlProgram class. This class returns 0 to indicate that it is not derived from ControlProgram. A derived class should reimplement this function and return "(ControlProgram *) this" only if it is derived from the class ControlProgram.

This function allows the framework to automatically setup and start the QMotor control program from the init() functions.

Returns:
A pointer to the QMotor control program object, will be usually "this".

Example: 

     class Motor : public PhysicalObject, public ControlProgram
     {
       ...
     
       virtual ControlProgram *getQMotorControlProgram()
       {
         return (ControlProgram *) this;
       }
     }

Member Data Documentation

const TypeInfoAbstractT< RoboticObject > s_typeInfo [static]
 

The static type info object of the class. Every class derived from RoboticObject must have this static data member and initialize it correctly.

Reimplemented in FunctionalObject, and PhysicalObject.

Status d_objectStatus
 

The current status of the object. In case of an error that occurs in the object, the object should set the d_objectStatus to "ERROR".

CGroup * d_controlPanelGroup [protected]
 

A group with vertical orientation that is a child of the control panel window.

CWindow * d_controlPanelWindow [protected]
 

The control panel window.
